title: 180000 brits are owed 5000 each after having their benefits underpaid by bungling officials
story: The Government will pay an average of £, to , disabled or ill claimants who were short-changed for years.The Department for Work and Pensions announced it faces a bill of nearly £billion for the blunder # three times as much as previously thought.It is the latest embarrassment for the department which is already under fire over the rollout of Universal Credit.Earlier this year, the DWP admitted it had underpaid thousands of claimants of Employment Support Allowance, which is intended for those too ill to work.Officials claimed , people were affected, with a total estimated cost of £million.But today they published an update which shows the numbers involved are much higher than previously thought.A total of , claimants are owed an average of £, each, with some due to be paid as much as £,.The overall bill to the taxpayer will be £million, most of which will be paid out over the next two years.Just  per cent of those affected have been paid the benefits they are owed.Civil servants are in the process of contacting the other , claimants and hope to be finished by next April.They are prioritising the most serious cases including those of people who are now terminally ill.Labour MP Neil Coyle blasted: #Another criminal let-down of thousands of disabled people by a callous Government and a chaotic DWP.#A spokesman for the DWP said: “Anyone affected by this historic error will receive all of the money they are entitled to.#That is why we have created a dedicated team of over  staff to examine cases, and have paid back around £million so far.“We have worked with charities and other disability organisations to make sure that we are providing the right support to all affected claimants and are hiring and allocating more staff to do that.”

title: theresa may needs to say no
story: The proposal to keep us shackled to the EU for another year beyond the transition period is an outrageous non-starter.We have compromised far too much. Mrs May cannot go further than her over-generous Chequers offer. This latest ruse is an insult she must repel.We would be in the farcical position of voting to Leave in June , yet still bound by Brussels rules until December  at the earliest. Which means continuing free movement, another £billion of public money tipped into EU coffers and no say over any of it.The Irish border problem is an overhyped stunt. The EU admits it would never build one even in a No Deal. Nor would we. Yet we are told we must buckle to their every whim to “avoid” such a border. Who would build it Mrs May is playing with fire even ­considering this new surrender.Unless she can give a date when we will leave the EU and ALL its major institutions she cannot claim to have fulfilled the referendum vote.When, PM, will we take back control FOR two years Leavers have had to suffer political has-beens being given s to bellyache about Brexit.Tony Blair, Nick Clegg and Michael Heseltine yesterday crossed the line into outright treachery.How  to describe their sickening appeal to the EU to frustrate exit negotiations long enough to buy Remainers time for a second referendum   A plea orchestrated to coincide with Mrs May’s crucial Brussels summit.Instead of backing Britain, and our historic decision, these meddling losers conspire with the EU to undermine our interests. The hypocrisy, arrogance and blinkered ­stupidity are jaw-dropping.Blair’s cabal claim to be motivated by “our support for democracy”.  It is a lie.A second referendum does not serve democracy. How could it  It is a naked attempt to reverse the biggest mandate in our history before it is enacted. It is the surest way to destroy trust in our ancient system and unleash chaos.John Major never consulted the public before signing away our rights to the new EU in . Nor did Blair when he threw open our borders.It was THEIR contempt for voters that built the resentment which led to Brexit.Now they are pouring petrol on the fire.YOU may not have heard of Noor Khan.She won a George Cross for bravery helping the resistance in occupied France during World War Two. She was tortured by the Gestapo but never cracked. The Nazis executed her in .Noor was just . A proper heroine.And a British Muslim.Many candidates’ pictures could grace the new £ note. Few are more deserving. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: mccauley cox woman run over newport nightclub
story: Cox mounted a kerb and drove over two female victims, leaving them with serious injuries.CCTV used in the trial shows Coxs car approaching a crowd of pedestrians outside the Courtyard nightclub, as a group begin fighting in the early hours of April .The car can then be seen clipping one of the pedestrians before darting forwards and swerving towards a group of people.Cox then ran over victims Sophie Poole and Emma Nicholls - before reversing back over them.Revellers then start to kick his Ford C-Max people carrier and confront him at either side of the vehicle.Police found the car later that day engulfed in flames. Cox said he decided to park it up after its engine began to smoke, and denied intentionally torching it.On Wednesday, Cox told his trial he accidentally ran over victims Miss Poole and Miss Nicholls after becoming frightened by revellers threatening to batter him in his vehicle, which he claims he had driven near the crowd of people to break up the fight.But prosecutor James Wilson accused Cox of using his vehicle to deliberately run over a man who was trading blows with his friend, only to miss and repeatedly run over the two young women, aged in their early twenties, who were sitting on a kerb.Mr Wilson said: Today you say you wanted to try and break up the fight.But you know full well you werent breaking a fight up. You were using the car as a weapon.You know full well the reason you went for that man is because he was confronting a friend of yours.You deliberately drove that car at that man with intent to cause him very serious harm.And you are responsible for those girls injuries because of your anger and annoyance at that man who was confronting your friend.Cox denied trying to hit the man, who has not been identied, and also denied knowing he had run over Miss Poole and Miss Nicholls, despite driving over and reversing over their bodies twice and subsequently having his car attacked by witnesses.It comes after Benjamin Thomas and Callum Banton, both , were pleaded guilty to affray and were jailed.Cox previously told the court: It felt like I hit something and I went into the air and came down and I was stuck.It was like it was stuck on top of something and I couldnt move forward.I werent paying attention properly. I wasnt thinking. I thought I hit a bin or a bollard.I only realised Id hit someone when I was arrested.He said he had been scared by people threatening him through his side window and had tried to flee by driving around the crowd of people and mounting the pavement.But Mr Wilson pointed out the pavement had been occupied by several pedestrians at the time, including victims Miss Poole and Miss Nicholls.Newport Crown Court had previously heard the university friends suffered really serious injuries after being repeatedly run over, with Miss Poole needing specialist skin grafts and Miss Nicholls suffering a lacerated spleen.Cox, from Newport, was remanded in custody and sentencing was adjourned until Friday morning.After the verdict, Kelly Huggins of the CPS, said: McCauley Cox used his vehicle as a weapon and caused an incident which left his victims with serious injuries.The CPS showed in court that his actions in driving his car into the crowd and reversing over those injured on two occasions amounted to this serious offence.

title: factory northfleet kent covered melted metal burns
story: The victim, aged in his s, suffered multiple deep burns to his head, neck, chest, abdomen and legs in the incident at a metal refining company in Kent.Emergency services raced to the factory which melts down metal in a high-temperature furnace.He was rushed to hospital with le-threatening injuries after the melted metal poured down upon him from above and doused his body.The liquid was believed to have inflicted severe burns which melted the skin on his head, neck, back, legs and abdomen in the horric accident at .am.Colleagues at the Britannia Refined Metals site in Northfleet, Kent, immediately rushed the young man into a shower to try to cool him down and paramedics were said to have spent almost two hours treating him and rushing him to hospital by land ambulance.Do you know who the man is  Email us at tips@the-sun or call   . You can WhatsApp us on   The victim was rushed to the Tunbridge Wells Hospital in Pembury, Kent.The factory said the employee was later transferred to the East Grinstead Hospital, a specialist burns unit in West Sussex, and that he had received emergency treatment for his injuries.His family had also been notied of the horric accident and he was now described as being in a stable condition.Britannia Refined Metals general manager, Florian von Steinkeller, said: An employee received burns following an ejection of hot metal.First aid was provided and emergency services were called. The employee was taken to Pembury Hospital and then transferred to East Grinstead Hospital. He is receiving treatment and is in a stable condition.The company has been in contact with the employee’s family to provide any help and support that may be required.The production area concerned was shut down so that a safety assessment could be made but has since been restarted.A full investigation of the incident will be carried out and further information will be provided when it is available.The plant refines metals such lead and silver and is involved in the the production of refined lead, lead alloys and silver from crude and scrap lead - but it is currently unknown which metal the victim was doused in.According to Mining Atlas, it is the largest primary lead producer within Europe, and is capable of producing more than , tonnes of lead and  tonnes of silver a year.A spokesman for Kent Police said today: “We were called to an industrial incident in Botany Road, Northfleet, at .am.“Officers attended the scene and provided support to crews from the South East Coast Ambulance Service, who conveyed a man to a local hospital.“The incident has been referred to the Health and Safety Executive.”

title: theresa may britain freedom eu
story: Not just the Brexiters. Her vital Scottish MPs. The moderates. The Remainers. Also the DUP on whom she relies.Barely enough people back her ­Chequers offer to hold their Christmas do in a Downing Street cupboard.And The Sun shares all their gloom.Mrs May admits we could extend the transition till . That the Irish backstop cannot be finite, so unless we have a watertight exit clause Brussels could lock us in its Customs Union for good.She must NEVER allow that.Yesterday the German chief economist of Deutsche Bank insisted thatwe can do deals with the US, Japan, Canada and the Commonwealth, Britain WILL thrive after Brexit and outstrip the EU.Exactly what Brussels fears.If the PM cannot secure our freedom to do all that, the game is up.NOT long ago crime was falling relentlessly.That’s all in the past. There has been an explosion of murders, rapes, robberies, knings, thefts and burglaries.Drug gangs rule our streets.Cuts have gone too far. We need more cops and ato Stop and Search.The upcoming Budget must free up more money to maintain law and order.But chief constables need to get a grip.Sergeant Richard Cooke, head of the West Midlands Police Federation, talks sense when he says officers waste time probing non-criminal “hate speech” and appeasing the “court of Twitter”.Our police chiefs need to get off their smartphones, ignore the “social justice” mob and refocus on keeping citizens safe.MUCH of the world is looking on aghast as Britain persecutes its own soldiers.Our No ally certainly is. Ex-Nato Commander General David Petraeus says the witch-hunt into veterans of the Troubles is wrecking our reputation as a reliable military partner. It may lead to “risk aversion” among current troops and “potentially limit their use of force”.So these probes have disastrous military implications as well as being an indefensible way to treat our forces.The Government must end them now. If legal challenges spring up, fight them.Grow a spine. Do the right thing.LABOUR considers the well-off a grasping elite whose cash must be given to the poor.They never consider how to grow an economy and create more wealth for all.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: eu leaders beer may tough brexit admission
story: National bosses went out drinking in Brussels without the PM, before then piling more pressure on her to come up with fresh compromises to break the Irish border deadlock.Mrs May was also forced to do battle on a second front back home as she also tried to quell a fresh Brexiteers rebellion.Eurosceptic Tory MPs erupted in fury over her confirmation yesterday that she is looking at extending the  month-long transition period to keep the UK under EU rules for even longer.During a second tense day at the EU summit:The extraordinary leaders drinking session came late on Wednesday night after a dinner to discuss Brexit without Mrs May broke up early.France’s Emmanuel Macron and Germany’s Angela Merkel stunned the Belgian capital by downing beers outside a café in its famous Grand Place for two hours.The powerful duo were joined by Belgian PM Charles Michel, Luxembourg’s Xavier Bettel and Sweden’s Stefan Lofven.Instead of joining them, Mrs May was holed up alone in the Brussels ambassador’s residence after being asked to leave before the  leaders’ dinner started.Accosted by two tourists over how the Brexit negotiations were going, Ms Merkel was reported to have replied: Please, its a wonderful evening - lets not spoil it with that.With the summit – dubbed in advance a “moment of truth” for Brexit - wrapping up in disappointment without a deal again, Mrs May admitted yesterday that “here is a lot of hard work ahead”.She added: “There will be more dficult moments as we enter the final stages of the talks, but Im convinced we will secure a good deal”.Quizzed by The Sun yesterday on what had gone at home and abroad, the PM insisted: “These were always going to be tough negotiations, and they were always going to get tougher as we got to the closing stages”.The PM also went to pains to calm Tory MPs’ anger over a longer transition period, arguing it would only be for “a matter of months” and that is still only “an idea at this stage”.An extension could be useful as “a further solution” to the Irish dilemma, she also said, as living a bit longer under EU rules until a trade deal is agreed would mean the hated Irish backstop that keeps Britain within an EU custons union would then never have to kick in.But Downing Street could not rule out having to fork out billions to stay under EU rules for longer, or that it would have any time limit.Former Tory Remainers and Leavers united in anger at the proposition.Former Tory minister and moderate MP Nick Boles led the backlash, lashing out at Mrs May to claim she “is losing the confidence of colleagues of all shades of opinion.Tory MPs are now close to despair at the state of Brexit negotiations, Mr Boles added.And former Brexit Secretary David Davis dubbed it a move “in the wrong direction”, adding: This is what the EU wants, so why are we offering it Mrs Merkel and Emmanuel Macron appeared to play a game of good cop   bad cop yesterday.The German leader held fresh one-to-one talks last night with Mrs May in a bid to come up with a breakthrough on Ireland last night.Mrs Merkel appeared to have softened her hardline on Brexit yesterday.Barely enough people back her ­Chequers offer to hold their Christmas do in a Downing Street cupboard.And The Sun shares all their gloom.Mrs May admits we could extend the transition till . That the Irish backstop cannot be finite, so unless we have a watertight exit clause Brussels could lock us in its Customs Union for good.She must NEVER allow that.Yesterday the German chief economist of Deutsche Bank insisted thatwe can do deals with the US, Japan, Canada and the Commonwealth, Britain WILL thrive after Brexit and outstrip the EU.Exactly what Brussels fears.If the PM cannot secure our freedom to do all that, the game is up.The PM gleefully quoted the Berlin boss as a sign of hope, saying: “Look at what Chancellor Merkel said, ‘Where there is a will there is a way’”.But the French president, who has always been the toughest on Britain, remained defiant, insisting that there would be “no additional political compromise on the EU side”.Instead insisting the ball was still in Mrs May’s court, Mr Macron said: “Now it is for Prime Minister May to propose a solution”.EU Council President Donald Tusk declared that “not enough progress has been achieved” to call a special summit in November to sign off any deal.But he also said the EU’s chief negotiator Michel Barnier had been instructed to keep the talks going.And a new Brussels summit will be called the moment the veteran Frenchman declares there has been a breakthrough on Ireland.Mr Tusk added: “I feel we are closer to a final solution but it is maybe more emotional impression than rational one”.It emerged last night that Mrs May’s inner sanctum Brexit Cabinet of  senior ministers had thrashed out the transition extension proposal at a tense meeting last Thursday.One senior minister told The Sun yesterday that the Cabinet would only accept a transition extension of “three to six months”, and no longer.But other members of Mrs May’s full Cabinet were “blindsided” by her transition extension announcement.The idea was also given reluctant and caveat-ed backing at a secret meeting of Cabinet Brexiteers over pizza on Monday evening, but only on the condition EU drop NI UK backstop demand.One Cabinet source said: Obviously this has gone down like a cup of sick but any transition with a named end date is preferable to an open ended backstop.“However it doesnt have a hope in hell in getting through unless it replaces the Northern Ireland only bit.A senior Government source added: “We need something to get the talks going again. If extending transition is an option they want to look at, we must go along with that. For us to say at this point that we’re not listening would not have been very sensible.”Business bosses backed a longer transitionit meant getting a deal.CBI Director-General Carolyn Fairbairn said: “Business’ patience was already threadbare and is nearing an end. The need for compromise on both sides to agree the Withdrawal Agreement and secure the transition period is long overdue.FILM legend Sir Michael Caine yesterday predicted furious business chiefs would force the EU to strike a Brexit deal.The multi-millionaire actor, , insisted he still believes in Brexit.He said it was better for the UK to be in charge of its own destiny than in hock to Eurocrats.In a BBC interview he said: “I’d rather be a poor master of my fate than having someone I don’t know making me rich by running it.”He suggested German car companies were the key to trade deals.The chief economist at Germany’s biggest bank has predicted the UK would thrive after Brexit.Deutsche Bank’s David Folkerts-Landau said yesterday Britain would do “just as well or better” after it leaves the EU.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: 40st darren mcclintock boxing
story: It’s not the first time a Sun reporter has had to dodge a punch but this time it’s a heavyweight trying to land one, with his personal trainer egging him on.Luckily for me, this heavyweight is st Darren “Dibsy” McClintock, whose obesity battle hit the headlines after his trainer Mike Hind banned takeaways from serving him.And even luckier, we have both just endured a -minute bootcamp workout at Mike’s gym — and as Dibsy tips the scales at nearly four times my body weight, it means I’ve got a bit more energy left than he has, enough to dodge his last few lunges in the boxing ring.But, exhausted and covered in sweat, Dibsy still gets awarded the winner’s belt in a light-hearted ceremony.It’s another encouragement dreamed up by Mike to give Dibsy the belief that he can win his personal battle of the bulge.His story — including his admission of weighing st rather than the st widely reported last week — has brought the UK’s obesity crisis into sharp focus.We are the third fattest nation in Europe, according to the World Health Organisation, and the North East, where Dibsy lives, is one of the most obese regions in the country.He has struggled with his weight all his le, and the death of his father from cancer when Dibsy was  didn’t help his increasing reliance on comfort-eating.Numerous efforts over the years to lose weight failed and his huge bulk now has a devastating effect on his le — he is single, he can’t get a job, he has to order specially-made clothes and when he goes on holiday he has to book two plane seats.Dibsy, , finally decided to act earlier this year when a heart scare landed him in hospital for a week and a doctor delivered the stark message: “Diet or die.”Married dad-of-three Mike heard about Dibsy’s plight and offered to take him under his wing for a year.He now puts him through his paces twice a day at his Mas Body Gym, in their home town of Middlesbrough, and provides all his meals from his newly opened healthy eating diner.Dibsy was consuming an alarming , calories a day — an average man needs around , — but was burning hardly any because he was so inactive.He is now down to , a day after ditching takeaways, booze and unhealthy snacks and, thanks to his new exercise regime, is burning , a day.The results are remarkable.On day one he couldn’t walk more than a few yards without getting out of breath.I joined him for a workout on day ten as he proudly announced: “I’ve lost ½st already.”The first exercise — just a warm-up, said Mike — involved flipping a huge, kg lorry tyre.Despite his weight, Dibsy isn’t lacking in upper body strength and he made it look easy — which it isn’t.We then moved on to pushing a metal sledge theof the gym and dragging it back the other way, with Mike holding on to make it harder.Then it was on to the kg slam ball session — hurling a medicine ball into the ground with as much force as you can.Next came smashing a sledgehammer on to the lorry tyre as hard as possible, as Mike yelled at us to do it harder.The innovative bootcamp exercises are designed in part to replicate the physical exercise people might do in their daily jobs, and are perfect for Dibsy.Mike, , explained: “He is too big for conventional gym equipment, so we need to get him doing something dferent.“You work with what you’ve got and using this equipment we have devised a set of exercises that put him through it without creating too much strain on parts of his body that can’t handle it yet.“We also have a heart monitor on him all the time which gives a real-time readout of his heart rate and calorie burn rate.“The strain on his heart is something we need to keep an eye on, soit gets too much we ease off and let him rest.“We also need to make sure he doesn’t overheat, sohe is getting a bit hot we use a leaf blower to cool him down.”By then we were both shattered, but there was little time for rest as Mike moved us into the boxing ring.“Don’t hit him too hard, Dibsy,” instructed Mike. “Or not at all ”, I suggested.Thankfully, Dibsy was just about done in — the heart monitor revealed he had burnt , calories that session — and I could keep him at arm’s .Afterwards he told me how he had got so heavy.He said: “I have never been skinny but the weight started really going on in my early teens.“I have never been sporty andmy mates went to the park for a kickabout I’d just sit it out because you are embarrassedyou can’t run around with them.“My family say that my dad dying of cancer at , when I was , had a big effect, but I’m not so sure.I wouldn’t blame my weight on that, it’s down to me and no one  that I am this size.“I have been seeing doctors and dieticians for years and my weight would go up and down.I lost st at one stage but it went back on.“People do say things in the street or stare and kids call me ‘Fatty’.That obviously hurts, so I go home and comfort-eat to make me feel better, which puts more weight on, which attracts more comments. It’s a vicious cycle.“I have had girlfriends and long-term relationships and I wouldn’t say I have lost them because of the weight.“But I am single now and being this size does affect that side of your le.“I knew I had to do something after I had my recent scare. It started when I began getting out of breath.It got worse and I could hardly breathe. It was terrying and I was taken to hospital.They said my heartbeat was all over the place. Normally they said they would give me some drugs and shock my heart so the beat gets back to normal.“But they had no idea how much drugs to give me — they were scared I wouldn’t wake up.So instead they gave me beta blockers and blood thinners and basically hoped I didn’t have a heart attack.“I was in hospital for a week and a doctor came round and told me I couldn’t keep doing this.“He saidsomething didn’t change, I was heading for an early grave. To see the look on my mother’s face when he said that was heartbreaking.I have never had a doctor be so straight with me before and I decided that this time I had to do it for real.“I didn’t know Mike but I had heard of his new diner which serves healthy food so I went down with my mum and got chatting to the staff.“He got to hear about my plight and messaged me to say he could help. The next day I went to see him and he asked me about my le and what I hoped to achieve.“It was pretty emotional when we talked about what the doctor had said. My mum said she didn’t want to bury her child and we all ended up in tears.“Mike agreed to help, both with an exercise plan and a meal plan. It was intimidating going into the gym for the first time. I have been to gyms before but it has never worked for me.“But at Mike’s gym everyone is so encouraging and wants me to succeed. And the support Mike gives me away from the gym is incredible. He texts me about  times a day to check I am OK.“One evening, a couple of days into my new exercise regime, I was at home and I messaged him to say I was struggling. It was a night that I’d usually have a takeaway and I was missing it.“Without a moment’s hesitation he said, ‘I’ll see you at the gym in ten minutes’. I said, ‘But the gym is closed’. He replied, ‘I own the gym — see you there’.“We did a -minute workout and I got home exhausted and went to bed, really pleased with myself.“It’s support like that which is getting me through. I want to learn to drive and get back into work.I used to work in a chemical plant but got laid off.Since then it has been impossible to get another job because of my size.BREAKFAST: Two sausage sandwicheswith a pint of FantaMID-MORNING SNACK: Packet of crispsLUNCH: Chicken sandwich with full-fat mayonnaise, packet of crisps, a pasty and bottle of CokeDINNER: Huge plateful of chicken curry, rice, naan bread and spring rolls – plus a ham sandwich while that meal is cooking. Served with another pint of FantaSUPPER: A takeaway parmo , kebab or pizzaDRINKS: Dibsy only drank alcohol at weekends. But a typical Sunday session involved  cans of Strongbow Dark Fruit cider, ten Southern Comfort and lemonades and six JagerbombsWHAT’S A CHICKEN PARMO  Teesside delicacy, consisting of deep-fried chicken breast covered with bechamel sauce and cheese,“Work clothes don’t fit and I’m obviously a massive health and safety risk.“SoI can lose weight I will get back into work and will have less time at home, thinking about eating.”Mike takes one obese person under his wing every year to get them fit.It’s his way of giving back to the community which helped him to launch his gym with a crowdfunding appeal in .He is providing all of Dibsy’s meals free for a year, plus two training sessions a day, which would normally cost £,.As The Sun reported last week, knowing Dibsy’s big love of takeaways, Mike came up with the idea of a leaflet which he distributed to local fast food places, saying: “Do not serve this man.”Dibsy loved parmos — a local delicacy of chicken in breadcrumbs, deep fried and covered in bechamel sauce and cheese, amounting to , calories.Mike said: “His target weight is st and we will get there.His family is on board, I am on board, but most importantly Dibsy is on board.“That is vital with any addiction, admitting you have a problem and wanting to do something about it.“We will not fail.”BREAKFAST: Overnight oatswith berriesLUNCH: Omelette with green beans and broccoliDINNER: Jamaican jerk chicken and white rice or steak meatballs and pasta with broccoliDRINKS: Dibsy has ditched fizzy drinks and alcohol. title: qatar saudi blockade world cup on track
story: “Qatar could be an island when the World Cup kicks off,” tour leader Irshad Nawaz, , reveals.The Saudis are threatening to excavate a -mile long, -yards wide canal along the border, cutting off the Qatari peninsula from the mainland.And just to rub sand into the wounds, Riyadh wants to convert part of the border area into a nuclear waste burial site and military base.It’s not exactly something Qatar is boasting about in its  World Cup PR bumpf.In a region riven with rivalries, Qatar has fallen out spectacularly with neighbours including Saudi, the UAE, Bahrain and Egypt over its alleged ties to terrorism.In June , its foes started a land, sea and air blockade designed to put the gas-rich land back in its box. Saudi slammed shut Qatar’s only land border and barred state-owned Qatar Airways from its airspace.For a nation that imported much of its food and goods, it might have been calamitous. Yet little Qatar — it is smaller than Yorkshire and expecting to host .million football fans in  — has fought back.In the lunar-like landscape  miles north of capital Doha is a farming complex where black and white Holstein cows munch fodder in air-conditioned sheds. All , of them were brought in from Germany, Hungary and the US since the blockade began.It’s led to bosses at Baladna Farm being hailed as the milk sheikhs.Its marketing manager Mark Somogyi tells me: “Before the blockade at least  per cent of dairy products were from abroad. Today Qatar is practically self- sufficient in fresh milk, as little as three per cent is imported. Nobody foresaw the blockade but the country is coping very well.”So what of the vast World Cup building preparations under the blockade, which sees most goods now arriving at Hamad Port In an exclusive tour, Qatari organising committee officials were keen to show stadium preparations were on schedule.Seven futuristic arenas are rising out of the desert with one revamped, aircon blasted ground — the Khala International — already finished.For this is the World Cup where money is no object. For brimming with petro dollars, Qatar is the richest nation on Earth. At the Al Wakrah Stadium, nine miles from Doha, the seats are already going in.Modelled on traditional dhow fishing boats, the ,-capacity stadium may host games up to the quarter final stage. The pristine pitch is like a green oasis amid the construction dust where , migrant workers toil.Inside what will be a players’ dressing room, Mohammed Emaran, , is sealing plasterboard where Gareth Southgate could be giving his team-talk in four years.The labourer — who earns around £ a month for a six-day week with free lodging and food — says: “I’m happy with the work and send money home to my family in India.”Yet two migrant workers have perished during construction work at the £million arena.Anil Kumar Pasman, , from Nepal, died at Al Wakrah after being hit by a lorry in . And a -year Nepalese scaffolder fell to his death on August . He is believed to be the first reported fatality at a tournament venue since January , when British construction worker Zac Cox, , died helping refurbish the Khala International Stadium.Yet one union has claimed , people have been killed working on projects for the  tournament, a claim vehemently denied by Qatari officials. Qatar’s World Cup organising body, the Supreme Committee for Delivery and Legacy, says the Nepali scaffolder’s death is still being investigated.Project manager Thani Khala Al-Zarraa, , says of the latest tragedy: “Half an hour after I heard the news I gathered , workers at the stadium. I told them, ‘You came here to support your family, so whatever health and safety instructions we tell you is for your own good, so that you go back to your families’.“But in construction you cannot eliminate all risk. Mistakes happen.”Qatar’s £billion spend on World Cup infrastructure has eased the financial pain of the blockade for many of the .million population.Doha is currently a vast building site as new tower blocks rise and a three-line metro system is constructed. More than  greenhouses have been built in the desert amid hopes to become self-sufficient in vegetable production by .Some England fans had planned to stay in Dubai and fly in and out for the games. But direct flights have been canned under the blockade.The Middle East’s first World Cup will also have a shortfall of hotel rooms. But there are “glamping” sites in the desert while cruise ships moored in the Gulf will also provide accommodation.Yesterday Qatar was sweltering in the muggy, low Cs. But during the tournament — from November  to December  — it should be a balmy  to C. Still, a thirst-quenching beer might be out of the question.It is unclear what the rules on alcohol sales will be in a Muslim land under Sharia Law, where drinking in public is banned. Five-star hotels serve alcohol, but £ for a bottle of beer is commonplace.Budweiser told The Sun it will be an official sponsor at the Qatar World Cup — but can’t yet confirm whether it will be allowed to sell its beer at stadiums and fan festivals.Travelling supporters could also take in a camel race at the Al Shahaniya race track an hour outside Doha.After Qatar banned child jockeys in , the camels have been ridden by robots in racing silks.Another unusual sight is the desert scrapyard at Al Wukair, where around , vehicles, including cars, boats, lorries, buses, bulldozers and cranes, languish in the dust. organising committee boss Hassan al Thawadi insists: “The blockade hasn’t hindered our preparations. We had to find alternative suppliers . . .  and since then projects are still on track.”In Qatar’s beating heart, Doha’s Souk Waq market, locals have turned beating the blockade into a matter of national pride.World Cup replica hawker Ahmed Khala, , sells at least one £ le-size replica copy of the gold Fa trophy a day alongside tea mugs fashioned in the shape of niqab-clad women.Ahmed says: “Why didn’t they do a blockade before Qatar won the right to stage the World Cup  They’re jealous Qatar has the tournament.”If the blockade is still in place come , Three Lions fans will at least be guaranteed a decent cuppa.All thanks to the milk sheikhs of Arabia.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit revolt lord bridges theresa may
story: Lord Bridges has joined a growing revolt against the PM after she admitted Britain could stayed tied to the EU for another  months.It could mean abiding by all Brussels rules until December  at the earliest,  months longer than No’s current transition plan.Her concessions have enraged Remainers and Leave voters - and she now faces a make-or-break week.Lord Bridges, who served in the Brexit department between July  and June , is the latest in a growing number joining a chorus of anger.The Times reports a growing number of MPs are plotting to install David Davis as interim PM.Leave-backing Tory MPs met on Wednesday to discuss issuing letters of no confidence in the PM, the paper reports.It would need  letters to trigger a challenge.A senior Conservative source said the “current was flowing” against the Prime Minister.Meanwhile, groups representing more than  Tory Remainers had their own meeting to discuss how to block a no-deal Brexit.Nick Boles, former skills minister, accused May of trying to run down the clock and said the Conservatives were “close to despair”.May also failed to dispute claims by Ireland’s Europe minister, Helen McEntee, that she had scrapped demands for a fixed end date on her plan.The concession could mean continuing free movement of all migrants, as well as the UK having to fork out another £bn into EU coffers in fees, while having no say in any Brussels decision making.Mrs May left yesterdays dinner in Brussels after a half-hour speech, as the other  leaders enjoyed a meal of turbot cooked in beer.But Tory MPs lined up to slap down her suggestions just minutes later.Andrea Jenkyns agreed, told ITVs Peston: It’s ludicrous that it’s two years on and we haven’t got a deal. Extending [the transition] just kicks it into the long grass.Nigel Farage added: This is another betrayal of Brexit... I dont think she can survive this.He speculated it could mean British taxpayers having to pay an extra £BILLION to the EU.But Tory Deputy Chairman James Cleverly played down the suggestion of extending the transition period - pointing out that it was only a proposal from the EU.

title: meghan markle yoga pregnant prince harry bondi beach
story: The Duke and Duchess of Sussex visited a surfing and yoga group on Bondi Beach, with Meghan saying the Oz coast was so good for healing your mind.They are on day four their official -day Autumn tour visiting cities in Australia, Fiji, Tonga and New Zealand.Meghan and Harry visited the famous beach for Fluro Friday, a session aimed at mental health awareness which included an anti-bad vibes circle and yoga practice.Charlotte Connell, , was at the beach with her son Finn and said: Meghan told me that pregnancy was like having jet lag.She said she was up at .am this morning doing yoga in her room as she couldnt sleep.Its a bit of a double whammy for her, she said, as she has both the baby and jet lag to contend with.The couple arrived to cheers at .am, with Meghan wearing a stripy maxi dress by Martin Grant and Harry a blue shirt and chinos.They were both presented with leis - a pink garland for Meghan and a blue one for Harry - and both took their shoes off before walking along the beach.The duke and duchess met members of OneWave grouo which holds the Fluro Friday mental health sessions weekly.They then went on to meet the leguard stars of TV show Bondi Rescue - who presented the couple with a leguard outfit for their forthcoming baby.Leguard Jake Nolan, who has previously met Harry on Bondi Beach, said: We had a bit of a laugh because last time he was here he was out for a run and he said Last time I was a bit sweaty when I met you.We got them a little leguard unorm - mini shorts, mini shirt.Anthony Carroll, known as Harries, added: It was amazing, theyre such beautul, down-to-earth people.

title: creepy moment dad claims he spotted ghost peering out from behind door as he tests new baby monitor
story: Video footage of the so-called “apparition” has been viewed by hundreds on YouTube channel The Hidden Underbelly ..Beneath the video, an explanatory note says that while testing out the camera on the new monitor, “this father filmed more than he bargained for.“As the new father moves the controls of the camera to view his we, he catches a glimpse of a figure at the doorway before it vanishes.”The dad can be heard in the clip asking the mum, who is in another room with the baby: “Can you move these things left or right as well… oh, you can”, as he tries to figure out how to use the device, which is focused on the cot.Pressing the buttons on the monitor, he continues: “Let me checkI can um, get your face.Suddenly he swears: “What the f***  Lisa, what’s behind ya ”A head can be seen popping up momentarily in the frame, before disappearing.The dad tears through the house towards the baby’s room, trying to find outanyone  is in the house, before checking behind the door.Finding no one there, he tells the mum, “I swear to God” that he saw someone behind the door.The video has received a mixed reaction from viewers, with several saying the video looks “fake”.But one person said: “It doesn’t look human. It appears to have a demonic face.”Another posted: “Paranormal Peeping Tom.”One, however, took a more flirty stance, saying that while they weren’t impressed with the “little demon, the father’s Irish accent seems nice.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: look inside 1930s house for sale
story: The detached home in Cross Hands, near Llanelli, was built in  and has changed very little since that time - even the furniture is from that era.It has remained in the same family since the keys were first handed over in , but the current owners have reluctantly put the property, called Heol Bryngwili, on sale for £, so they can downsize.The house has many art deco features such as led crittal windows and a first floor balcony.Originally the house may have had a typical flat roof style but it has since been redone with a pitched roof.An authentic glass-led front door leads to a hallway with its original woodwork and a built-in telephone and seating area.Throughout the property are deep coving and skirting boards as well as solid wood led interior doors.Over the crittal windows in the front reception room are decorative window pelmets featuring a classic stepped design.There is also a tiled fireplace topped with an arched alcove.It was common in the s for the front room to be the location for entertaining guests, known as the parlour, while the rear sitting room would have been a casual space for the family to relax.The small kitchen was redone in the s and has white cupboards with pale blue worktops.The adjoining boiler room, side entrance hallway and pantry could all be incorporated to make a larger kitchen under the management of a new owner.Three large bedrooms occupy the first floor of the house, with the master bedroom at the front.Meanwhile the bathroom features original s detailed green tiling, which is hard to find in any home today.The bath, which may have been replaced as it does not have the classic roll-top, has a canopy over it.The bathroom also features a s style basin and taps, ceiling coving and window pelmets.The rear garden is large and there is also a lawned area at the side of the property.There is a garage and workshop at the back of the land.The owners are reluctantly selling the property for £, with estate agent Clee Tompkinson Francis Carmarthen branch.They are hoping for the new owners to retain the s decor of the house and are willing to negotiate for the furniture to be included in the sale.It is a unique opportunity to be able to buy a house with its traditional decor so well intact.

title: brexit deal theresa may brussels summit
story: Brexiteers called on the PM to get some steel - and warned they will block any attempt to pay in more to the EUs budget.But Mrs Mays ally Jeremy Hunt stood up for her - claiming the only reason Brexit talks are in trouble is because of her firm negotiating strategy.The PM said yesterday that she would consider keeping Britain tied to the EU for an extra year in order to reach a Brexit deal.But Brexit backers in her own party have responded with anger to the plans for extending the transition period until the end of .Iain Duncan Smith told the BBC: I couldnt understand why we would offer to extend the transition period when we still havent got anything back in .By extending the backstop we are likely to fall straight into the next budget of the EU which will mean tens of billions of pounds extra to be paid across to the EU.We are in a negotiation but at the moment it begins to look more like a capitulation than a negotiation.We have got to get some steel in our backbone.Brexiteers are threatening to use a Commons vote to block any extra money going to the EU beyond the £billion already promised.They want to amend the Finance Bill to ban ministers from handing additional cash to Brussels without the permission of Parliament.Andrea Jenkyns told the : Its absurd that there is to be a Budget before the final Brexit deal.That is effectively writing a blank cheque to the EU and that leaves the danger that Article  may be extended with full funding.And Priti Patel urged Mrs May to channel the spirit of Margaret Thatcher by refusing to fork over any money to the EU budgetEurocrats continue to stonewall.Mr Hunt insisted the PMs tough stance is working - because she has refused to fold to the EUs demands.He told the BBC today: The reason why this week has been dficult is because Theresa May has not buckled. She has held firm. She has stuck to her principles.It is precisely because she has not capitulated that we have not concluded this agreement.The one thing I would say to my colleagues is that the great strength of the EU in these negotiations is that the  EU nations have remained united.We now need to do the same behind Theresa May to maximise her negotiating leverage in Brussels and make sure she does come back with that deal that honours the letter and spirit of the referendum decision.But Mrs May faces opposition from within her own Cabinet - Scotland Secretary David Mundell told No yesterday he wont accept a longer transition period.Scottish Tories are angry at the prospect of Britain signing up to the Common Fisheries Policy for another year.The EUs Brexit envoy Michel Barnier today said a deal is  per cent done.But he added: I’m convinced a deal is necessary, I’m still not sure we’ll get one.

title: driver forces couple dumping baby clothes pickup rubbish
story: The Good Samaritan blasted the pair after spotting them leave two full bags of rubbish at the corner of Dyson Road in Halax, West Yorkshire, at around pm on Monday.The shameless man and woman even claimed they were dumping the bags for charity when the driver intervened and demanded they stop littering near his home.When challenged, the woman said she was entitled to leave it in the street because she was giving the items to people who needed them.But the couples excuses cut no ice with their accusers and they were forced to pick up their bags and haul them away.The local council is now investigating the incident and has said authorities will not hesitate to prosecute those responsible for fly tipping.Video footage of the confrontation - filmed by a car passenger - shows him wind down his window and order the couple to go back and pick them bags up”.A blonde woman approaches the car and says: Its a bag full of clothes, for babies.When the man tells her the roadside is not a clothes bank, she replies: Well, it used to be there.He blasts: Go back and pick them up. F****** dump rubbish here, we live here.The car follows the pair down the street to the spot where the bags were dumped, as the woman protests: I was giving it to the people who needed the baby clothes.Unmoved by her story, the man replies: Theres no people on that corner who need it, so pick them up.He then spots a large object protruding from one of the open bags and asks: Does that look like baby clothes to you ”To which she responds: There are toys as well.The couple then pick up their bags and slope off, as the passenger brands them disgusting.The woman - who still apparently feels she has done nothing wrong - turns and asks: What, for helping people out Infuriated by her lack of remorse, the man shouts back: Dumping stuff on the floor. Who you helping  Yourself The hero who filmed the incident did not wish to be identied but viewers who saw the footage on social media were full of praise for his efforts.Tayyab Zahoor said: “That’s disgusting. Good job making them clean it.”Elaine White wrote: Well done to the lads that stopped and said something. Your community should be proud of you.Dilshad Hussain added: Make them clean the whole street next time.Calderdale Council told The Sun Online: “The Council does all it can to stop fly-tipping and will not hesitate to prosecute those responsible.Although this instance has not been previously reported to us, we will now investigate, as we do with all reports.“In all cases, having as much information as possible helps to bring successful prosecutions, so the Council is urging people to come forwardthey witness any fly-tipping.West Yorkshire Police said the incident has not been reported to officers.

title: copy of abbas dancing queen signed by theresa may is sold for 2700 after her onstage boogie
story: The Prime Minister was asked by Pink News to sign a vinyl record of the vintage hit for their charity auction.Staff came up with the idea after Mrs May boogied on stage to the track during the Conservative party conference in Birmingham earlier this month.The single was auctioned off during the publication’s annual awards at Church House in London this week.Celebrities and politicians were among those bidding for the iconic tune during a silent auction for Kaleidoscope Trust.The charity supports LGBT people across the world and helps ensure their human rights are upheld.Home Secretary Sajid Javid dubbed the Prime Minister “Britain’s best ABBA tribute act” in his speech before presenting the campaigner of the year award.Guests at the star-studded bash included Sir Vince Cable, Jeremy Corbyn, Tony Blair and Will Young.The annual awards celebrates the contributions of entertainers, politicians, campaigners, businesses and community groups to improving LGBT le in the UK and the world.Mrs Mays signed record sold to Angie Moxham from The Fourth Angel PR company for £,.

title: doctors remove eleven live worms baby eye
story: The five-month-old caught a horric roundworm infection from the neighbours pet.The child, known as Dong Dong, was taken to was taken to the Xi’an No.  Hospital in north-west China after mum noticed irritation in the tot’s eye.Medics examined Dong Dong and found several wriggling worms on the surface of the eyeball.Using special tweezers doctors were able to remove the grim creatures, which are believed to be Thelazia callipaeda – a parasitic roundworm.It took  minutes for doctors to remove the worms, plucking them out one at a time using tweezers.The worms most often affect cats, dogs and other animals, but can be passed on to humans.Termed ‘oriental eye worm’, the majority of cases occur in Asia, where it occurs predominantly in rural communities with poor living and socioeconomic standards, according to the UK Department ofor Environment, Food and Rural Affairs.A small number of human cases have been reported in Europe in areas where the infection is well established in domestic animals, like dogs and cats.Usually cases in humans cause clinical signs of exudative conjunctivitis, watery eyes and pain, but asymptomatic infection is recorded.If youre concerned you may have a roundworm infection you should see a doctor.Dong Dong is continuing to receive treatment but is expected to make a full recovery.

title: black panther ayshire on loose
story: Cops are asking residents to be vigilant and do no not approach the big cat spotted in fields in Ayrshire.Have you seen the black panther  Call The Sun Online newsdesk on    or email sam.christie@the-sunAyrshire Police have urged dog walkers to steer clear of the animal following the reported sighting today at .am between the villages of Drongan and Coalhill.A helicopter was scrambled to help with the search for the big cat which may be injuredCops confirmed that an animal expert had veried that the animal was a panther.An Ayrshire Police spokesman said: Residents in Drongan and Coalhall are being advised by officers to be vigilant after a report has been received of a sighting of what is believed to be a black panther in the fields near to the B between the two villages.Officers are currently working with the SSPCA to locate the animal which may be injured.The area is popular with dog walkers so care should be taken andanyone sees the animal we would ask you not to approach it, but to contact Police via  quoting incident number  of Friday  October .The area is popular with dog walkers and there are two schools in Drongan.Scottish SPCA Animal Rescue had been liaising with police but are unequipped to deal with a black panther.Last month a terried mum claimed to have spotted the Beast of Cumbria stalking the countryside.The mysterious creature is said to be at least three times the size of a normal domestic cat — and locals say it feasts on livestock.Last year a big cat was snapped prowling through the grass at a picnic spot in Somerset.Earlier this year cops were called to tackle a tiger on the loose — and found a giant cuddly toy.Worried Bruce Grubb, , who reported the fearsome big cat lurking on his farm near Peterhead, said: “I got the fright of my le.”He called in armed officers when he spotted the striped creature crouched on a ramp in the animals’ barn.When police arrived, they stayed safely inside their vehicles during a tense hour-long stand-off as they tried to work out how best to tackle the beast.

title: michel barnier brexit nostalgic
story: Brussels’ chief negotiator said people were “not told all the consequences” before choosing to quit the bloc in June .Speaking on French radio, he said: I wouldnt confuse belief in the free market with nostalgia.Mr Barnier added: Brexit cant be soft. It has innumerable consequences. It was chosen by the British.Were they well informed at the time they voted  They were not told all the consequences.And he warned the talks could still collapse over the thorny Irish border issue after this week’s EU summit ended in stalemate.The Frenchman told Theresa May that whatever happens the split from Brussels will be “much more grave for Britain” than the rest of Europe.He said EU capitals were preparing emergency solutions to cope with a no deal Brexit but that a crash out would still be extremely serious.Mr Barnier said: I dont want to impose a hard Brexit. A hard Brexit is the absence of a deal and I am working for a deal.The Frenchman also blasted Eurosceptics saying that they had not been able to prove there will be any added value in Brexit.His remarks came as Tottenham Hotspur boss Mauricio Pochettino described the decision to leave as a car crash and urged Mrs May to put the brakes on.The Argentinian said he feels sorry for the British public who still don’t know the consequences of Brexit.He said: I feel so sorry because it’s a situation that should be dealt with by people who have all the information, who know the reality.“It’s so unfair to put the responsibility on the people because there are consequences.We said Brexit, we bought into an idea. But afterwards, who suffers  We don’t know.

title: facebook hires ex deputy pm nick clegg as top spin doctor in shock move
story: The former deputy PM will move to Calornia to lead the social media giants communications team.It will be the first time the ex-MP will hold a job in the private sector for  years.Sir Nick, , lost his Commons seat to Labour last June, two years after quitting as leader of the Lib Dems.He said today: I am delighted to be joining Facebook. After almost twenty years in European and British politics, this is an exciting new adventure for me.Having spoken atto [company bosses] Mark and Sheryl over the last few months, I have been struck by their recognition that the company is on a journey which brings new responsibilities not only to the users of Facebook’s apps but to society at large.I hope I will be able to play a role in helping to navigate that journey.He landed the lucrative Facebook post as the controversial web firm scrambles to rescue its public image.The company has been accused of allowing dodgy governments to rig elections in the West, as well as enabling the spread of fake news.Boss Mark Zuckerberg was forced to admit he hadnt thought enough about the political impact his website could have.Sir Nick will be in charge of global affairs and communications after Facebooks previous spin doctor quit this summer.He was locked in talks with Mr Zuckerberg about the role for months, according to the Financial Times.Company no Sheryl Sandberg called Sir Nick a thoughtful and gted leader as she welcomed him to the firm.As well as boosting the firms links with the UK, hiring Remainer Mr Clegg could help Facebooks relations with Brussels.David Camerons former deputy has spent the past two years campaigning for a second referendum on Brexit.He will start work in London soon before moving to Facebooks headquarters in Silicon Valley.A Lib Dem source told The Sun: Its ironic that Nick is leaving the country just before were supposed to quit the EU. Is this a sign he thinks a second referendum isnt going to happen Sir Nick is married to high-flying lawyer Miriam González Durántez, and the couple have three children.He said: Miriam and I have been so grateful for the warm welcome extended to us by everyone we have met at Menlo Park.Moving to Calornia is a new beginning for us – and for our three sons – which we are looking forward to with great excitement and anticipation.Labour hit out at his appointment - shadow minister Jon Trickett said: It is a damning indictment of the sorry state of our countrys politics that, at a time when digital giants such as Facebook are rightly coming under public scrutiny, our former Deputy Prime Minister has been hired to lobby on their behalf.Jeremy Corbyns deputy Tom Watson quipped: They were both cool in .

title: woman breeds zonkey only uk zebra donkey pet
story: Kristine Turner, , cant rein in her excitement over the adorable foal, named Zippy, after it was born at her farm in Somerset.The pet-mad mum-of-two had been champing at the bit for her pet zebra Ziggy and donley Rag to mate.Id wonder every yearshe was pregnant or just a bit fat, Kristine told The Sun Online.You could put the randiest of animals out there - which I have done in the past - and nothing!”Just putting the two together isn’t enough to guarantee that they will mate, which is very dficult to do because of the black and white dferences between the species.But finally after donkeys years of waiting the amazing zonkey was born.Kristine added: “It feels amazing to be honest, I couldn’t believe it. When I looked out the window I was just going ‘Oh my god, oh my god!’”She says that she didnt even have a vet confirm that the zebra was pregnant because she didnt want to cause the animal any distress.Although Zippy is one of the first zonkies to be born in Britain, others have been brought over from abroad to live here.Three zonkies were born in Colchester Zoo in the s following the accidental mating of a zebra and an ass, and more recently several zebra hybrids from America were rescued by a UK donkey sanctuary.A zonkey belongs to a group of hybrids called ‘zebroids’, in which a zebra mates with a dferent kind of equine animal.Other zebroids include zorses , and zebmules .Kristine’s dad Bill Turner, , is a race horse trainer who made headlines when he “broke in” a zebra of his own back in  so that he could successfully ride it like a horse, despite zebras being notoriously panicky and near-impossible to domesticate.It was after seeing her father’s remarkable feat that she had a zebra of her own brought over from Germany.

title: children devon primary school vacuum class rooms save money
story: Hilary Priest, head teacher of The Grove School in Totnes, Devon, said the new measure cuts the caretakers workload and teaches respect.Each of the schools  classrooms has a vacuum cleaner which pupils use on a rota.Ms Priest says she was inspired after watching a television programme about education in Japan.She said: We thought it was a good way to make sure everyone and the children respect our school and respect our environment.But there is one class exempt from cleaning duties: reception, who are just a bit [too] little, Ms Priest said.Asked whether he and his classmates should have to pitch in and clean, Noah from year six said: Yes, its protecting our school.His classmate Imogen said: My mum said its good because then, when youre a grown-up, you know how to use the hoover.Ms Priest said the child-cleaners were also helping the schools budget.She added: We dont have to increase our caretakers hours in fact, he hasnt had to do much hoovering in any of the classrooms since we started about three months ago.It is not the first time people around the world have been impressed with the Japanese attitude to cleanliness.Football fans at the  World Cup in Russia looked on in awe as Japan supporters meticulously cleaned up their rows and seats in stadiums after a game.In  students in Singapore were also given daily cleaning duties.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: pro eu activists set to march through london calling for second brexit referendum as pressure mounts on theresa may

title: theresa may is in a perilous bind on brexit
story: But for now the absence of a breakthrough will be less important to the prime minister than the absence of a breakdown.The mooted special November summit to sign a withdrawal agreement may not be in the diary, but neither is the threatened "no-deal" November summit.The big hope appears to be that an extension to the implementation period, currently due to conclude in December , might provide space for the EU to consider a UK-wide form of Irish border backstop that wouldnt require Northern Ireland to be carved off into its customs union and single market. title: british mps who accepted thousands
story: NewsThe British MPs who have accepted thousands of pounds worth of benefits from Saudi ArabiaThe Kingdom has tripled the amount of money it spends lavishing gts, hospitality and overseas trips on British MPsShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter:,  OCT NewsTheresa May greeting Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman during his visit to Britain earlier this year "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSaudi Arabia has tripled the amount of money it spends lavishing gts, hospitality and overseas trips on British MPs, it has been revealed. It comes as the Kingdom is under suspicion over the alleged state-sponsored murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi. The Saudi government, including the crown prince, has denied any involvement in Mr Khashoggis disappearance. In , British parliamentarians accepted pound, of benefits from the Saudi regime, according to the Mail. But this year the figure is already three times higher at pound, - and it’s only October. The trips, which usually include business class travel and swanky hotel stays are supposed to be ‘working visits’ which give MPs a ‘better understanding’ of Saudi Arabia. Meanwhile, the UK continues its multi-billion pound arms trade with the Kingdom. Since , the UK has licensed almost pound billion worth of arms to Saudi Arabia, as they’ve waged their controversial war against Yemen.  Andrew Smith of Campaign Against Arms Trade said: “It shouldnt take the disappearance of a journalist for the UK to reconsider its relationship with the Saudi regime. Under Parliamentary rules, MPs have to declare gts and trips on the register of members’ interests. Here are some of the MPs who have accepted hospitality from Saudi Arabia, and what they declared. Theres no suggestion of any wrongdoing on the part of any of the MPs, and all benefits were declared properly. Leo Docherty - Conservative  Tory MP Leo Docherty lavished praise on Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed Bin Salman at Prime Minister’s Questions in March. But the Mirror revealed Mr Docherty had accepted pound, in paid for trips and flights from Saudi Arabia, visiting the Kingdom twice in six months. His first visit in September, just three months after he was elected, saw him meet with King Salman Abdulaziz bin Saud as well as senior government officials, “in order to support and understand the British-Saudi relationship.” And in January this year, he visited the Saudi-Yemen border region to “see impact of ballistic missile strikes in the Saudi Yemen border region and gain a deeper understanding of the strategic importance of the Coalition operations in Yemen.” He described Crown Prince Salman, who was visiting London at the time, “a force for tremendous stability in a very turbulent region.” Mr Docherty told the Mail: “It’s important to note that these visits are not “treats” or “donations” but working visits that take time and effort to a serious purpose – i.e. better understanding a key ally for our country.” Phillip Hammond - Conservative  A Watch worth pound,, from one of Saudi’s richest men. He declared it a private gt, given to him as an MP, rather than as Chancellor. Ministers are banned from accepting gts worth more than pound. His spokesman said civil servants had advised him the gt was not related to him being a minister. Stephen Metcalfe and Mark Garnier - Conservatives pound, for ‘flights, transport, food and accommodation’ for a visit to Saudi Arabia. Mr Metcalfe said: “I accepted on the basis it broadened my knowledge of Saudi Arabia.’ Mr Garnier wrote afterwards: “We should not force another society to adopt all our values.”

story: NewsopinionPoverty has moved from the dole queue to the workplaceAs its revealed that the Tory squeeze on wages means most workers are now earning less than they they did seven years ago, a senior economic analyst at The Resolution Foundation, Stephen Clarke, writes....ShareCommentsByMirror:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsopinionCuts made by George Osborne while he was Chancellor are still biting "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBritain has experienced a catastrophic decade for pay. Wages tanked in the wake of the financial crisis and, unlike in previous recessions, we’ve not had much of a recovery since. As a result, average wages are still pound a week lower in real terms than they were before Lehman Brothers collapsed. Some of the pay squeeze is down to an economy that has struggled to grow and become more productive. But it is also a result of government policy, with public sector workers having faced years of pay caps and freezes since . This research lays out the shocking impact of these real-terms pay cuts, with probation officers, paramedics and other health professionals among the hardest hit in their pay packets in recent years. Of course, it’s not all bad news. The lowest paid have benefitted from big rises in the minimum wage, particularly since .

title: ros wynne jones universal credit
story: NewsopinionRos Wynne-Jones: Universal Credit claimants want to know why no one listens to themRos Wynne-Jones has spoken to people who have written to Esther McVey about how to improve the controversial reformShareCommentsByRos Wynne JonesReal Britain columnist:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsopinionDiane Pottage, , at a stall to give people information about Universal Credit and ask them share experiences of poverty "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThis week, a letter arrived on the desk of Esther McVey, Secretary of State for Work and Pensions, from the ‘APLE Collective’ – with an offer of help. “We’d like to share our ideas and experiences on how Universal Credit could be improved, so it can help people to meet their aspirations and to leave poverty,” the letter said. The APLE Collective – Addressing Poverty through Lived Experience – is not a think tank. It’s made up of real poverty experts – Universal Credit claimants from places like Stockton-on-Tees and Salford. People who want to know why, in five years since the controversial benefit was first rolled out, no one has bothered listening to them. “The Government needs to start listening to people actually on Universal Credit,” Diane Pottage, , of Stockton, one of the letter authors told me. “We keep hearing it’s working. Well, I’m sorry, it isn’t. Butyou listen to us, we can tell you how to fix it.” Tory Brexiteers blast Theresa Mays plot to keep Britain tied to the EU for longer than plannedHer solutions are: “Stop the rollout to any more places, and take time to listen to the people who are on it. Go back to fortnightly payments. Stop the five-week wait for help.” This week – after two ex-Prime Ministers attacked the benefit, and Esther McVey finally admitted “some people will be worse off” – leaked documents suggested the Government is desperately seeking solutions to stop UC becoming the new Poll Tax. Yet, the voices of claimants are still being routinely ignored. Meanwhile, the Government fought Labour tooth and nail in Parliament this week to avoid releasing its own impact assessments of how people have been affected. Ministers tampered around the edges – delaying the rollout of UC for those on existing benefits. But, of course, people in low-paid work are always becoming ‘new claimants’ as one precarious job ends and they need help while they find another one. Meanwhile, at least , people with existing claims will still be ‘migrated’ to UC during . That may seem a small numberyou don’t have children to feed. “My social safety net is gone because of Universal Credit,” another of the letter’s authors, Letitia Rose,  from West Yorkshire, said. “It’s not just the way the benefit works, it’s all the pathetic administrative errors.” The next day the Government admitted wrongly underpaying , disabled people to the tune of poundbn. Patricia, , told me she was actually working at the Jobcentre when the new benefit came in – before needing to claim UC herself when the contract ended. “It’s not better for people, it makes things worse,” she says. “I don’t think politicians would survive a week on Universal Credit, let alone a full year.” Campaigners have been inspired by events in Scotland, where claimants are being brought into the design of benefits. In April, the Scottish Social Security bill enshrined in law ideas that “social security is a human right” and that “respect for the dignity of iniduals” must be at the heart of Scottish social security. Most workers earn less than they did seven years ago when Tories came into power“This is not just about people saying how bad things are – it’s recognising they have the expertise needed to address poverty,” says Ruth Patrick, a lecturer in social policy and social work at the University of York, who works with benefit claimant group Dole Animators. People with experience of poverty are not just case studies to be wheeled out. They should have a seat at the policy-making table.” This week, the poverty experts held a string of events nationwide to mark the International Day for the Eradication of World Poverty. Diane helped run a stall at Stockton Market, urging people to share their experiences. Letitia was involved with similar events in Salford. Patricia spoke movingly at the House of Lords. And UC claimants took over @wiganpier, our Wigan Pier Project twitter account. Five years after UC started, Diane’s own story is bitterly familiar – a six-week wait for help, then a wrong payment. “I’ve been to a food bank twice before and I’m not very far from needing one again,” she says. “The system is broken. My mum and dad were both working class but they weren’t going to a food bank.” The APLE Collective has yet to hear back from McVey, but the DWP say it has received the APLE Collective’s letter and will respond “in due course”. It says that with Universal Credit people are getting into work faster and staying in work longer. A spokeswoman added that “through our ‘test and learn’ approach we continue to listen to feedback from stakeholders and claimants and make improvements to the system”. Yesterday, I dug out the DWP’s press release from the first rollout in April . “Universal Credit is nothing less than the start of a fundamental cultural sht of the welfare system,” it proclaimed. “This will revolutionise the way people experience the welfare state.” A revolution that has cost hopes, dreams, potential, and even lives.

story: NewsTory Treasury minister to demand more local police officers despite his department cutting budgets by %Since  the policing budget in his region has been cut by £ millionShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter:,  OCT NewsTory MP and Exchequer Secretary Robert Jenrick "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA Tory Treasury minister has urged his constituents to call for more police officers despite his own department cutting local police budgets by %. Exchequer Secretary Robert Jenrick has sent out a survey to voters in his Newark constituency, asking for their experiences and perceptions of crime. He says he intends to use the results to push for increased police presence on the streets in an upcoming meeting with Northamptonshire’s Police and Crime Commissioner Paddy Tipping. Mr Jenrick, who owns two pound million homes in London, as well as a pound million country pile in his constituency, said: “Crime has become an area of concern for me. The message I am getting from residents is the town is under-policed.”  But Mr Tipping hit back, saying: “Mr Jenrick is a Treasury Minister. The corresponding figure for Nottinghamshire is poundm, or a % cut.” He added: “I will talk to him about the Prime Minister’s promise of ending austerity and be asking him to use his influence on her.” Louise Haigh, Labour’s Shadow Policing Minister said: “I agree with Robert Jenrick. title: my girlfriends arms ached hold
story: NewsMy girlfriends arms ached to hold our stillborn baby but I couldnt even bear to cut the cord, says dadBruce Wagstaffs partner Vicki Beckett was  weeks pregnant with their daughter Ruby when her heart stopped and he battled to cope with grief in the aftermathShareCommentsBySteve Myall:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsVicki and Bruce discovered Ruby had died at  weeks "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA dad who was filmed with his partner as she gave birth to their stillborn child has spoken about how he struggled to cope with the trauma of the loss. Bruce Wagstaffs partner Vicki Beckett was  weeks pregnant with their daughter Ruby when the unborn babys heart stopped. Heartbroken the -year-olds were sent home from the hospital and told tothe next day so Vicki could be induced and give birth to the baby. A TV documentary team making a programme about still birth were in the hospital and Vicki and Bruce agreed to let them film the birth.  The result is heartbreaking footage showing tearful Bruce and his partner delivering Ruby which will screen on TV tonight. Bruce told the Mirror: It was a Monday morning and we went in for scan but the midwe couldnt find the heartbeat. She called in a colleague for a second opinion but I could tell by her face it wasnt good. In  seconds my le changed forever. Tonight Channel  viewers will see Bruce after seeing his we go through  hours of labour unable to bring himself to cut the umbilical cord - which had planned to do had she lived. He said: It was a blur. We went home and then realised we had to call people and in may ways thats the hardest point. You hear a voice and dont know what to say, I just said shes gone, Rubys gone. It was massive shock.  When it came to cut the cord, I couldnt do it, I wanted to run out of the room. I just broke down, Vicki was so strong. However he did hold his baby adding: For  seconds I held her and it felt like she was really there. Following the birth Bruce struggled to be around his partner. He said: I couldnt face it. Her boobs were hurting because her body was producing milk but there was no baby to drink it. Her arms were aching because her body was telling her to hold her child. People forget a womans body has spent nine months preparing for birth, it doesnt just stop. After the birth it wasnt long before the grief became impossible for Bruce to bear, he explained: I thought I was a strong man and could deal with but I couldnt I wanted to get back to normal as soon as I could and couldnt be around Vicki who was grieving more openly.  After ten days we started to go our separate ways and then I went to see a counsellor which I am so glad I did. Bruce said: I went to see my brother in Spain and was just walking down the street when the anxiety hit me and I thought I was having a heart attack. It was the grief. I was so naive. Happily the couple reconciled and along with two other couples feature in Child of Mine on Channel .
